messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim: Good. I was worried that the recent deaths at the NBTHK might throw a monkey wrench into his plans. I have volunteered to Gordon to be a dog s body if
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim:
Good. I was worried that the recent deaths at the NBTHK might throw a
monkey wrench into his plans.
I have volunteered to Gordon to be a dog's body if I can be helpful in
the shinsa room as I am not having a table.
Stuart B has told me in two letters how pleased he was to see your
really top drawer material. Sounds wonderful.
Regards,
Arnold Frenzel

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Thanks Jim, that s what I wanted to know. I ve got a few very fine signed kinko tsuba that I d love to learn about--good mei or bad mei. Will see about
messages.messageBody:
Thanks Jim, that's what I wanted to know. I've got a few very fine signed kinko tsuba that I'd love to learn about--good mei or bad mei. Will see about submitting them!

Ron
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, June 29, 2004 9:28 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry


Ron,
He has a lot of shinsa experience with both the NTHK and NBTHK (Hozon/Tokubetsu Hozon, Juyo and Tokubetsu Juyo teams). I can't really pick out anything in particular. He has judged plenty of signed kinko work, so I wouldn't worry. In the few NTHK shinsa I've helped out at I've seen a fair amount of good, big name machibori kinko work pass shinsa (and of course gimei that have failed). The Chicago shinsa is a great opportunity to have your pieces evaluated.
Jim



Jim - I asked this earlier (maybe to Arnold, I don't recall), but what would be Hagihara sensei's strong points?

Ron
STL

messages.msgSnippet: Sadly Jim no, As you know our stay was cut short and one of the many things on my list of things to do at the end was attend one of the kodogu kansho-kai or
messages.messageBody:
Sadly Jim no,
As you know our stay was cut short and one of the many things on my
list of things to do at the end was attend one of the kodogu kansho-kai
or one of the Tokyo-shibu meetings (where they featured kodogu as well
as swords). Have to go back and get that done now won't we...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Tom, Do you know of any Xers focusing on the fittings side of things? Jim Jim et al- Don t give up hope yet. There were several Gen-Xers who were regular
messages.messageBody:
Tom,
Do you know of any Xers focusing on the fittings side of things?

Jim



Jim et al-
Don't give up hope yet. There were several "Gen-Xers" who were regular
attendees at the monthly kantei-kai. Most notably the young Mr
Fujishiro and his friends (there were always three or four), they
always dressed sharp and took the whole thing very seriously. While
others used the Dokuhon, they used only the Fujishiro Jiten and often
left early having sussed out the swords with their first bids. There
are young polishers and collectors out there, several young ladies who
study at the Sanno, and others who I am I am sure we never run into.
Who will be the next leaders? Can't say for sure but they are there...
-t


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Can t speak for the Gen-Xers, but I was into serious study and collecting antique knives and swords by my late teens. Had actually started collecting before
messages.messageBody:
Can't speak for the Gen-Xers, but I was into serious study and
collecting antique knives and swords by my late teens. Had
actually started collecting before that. No need to wait
until you're fifty something :-) Maybe things are/were
different in Japan.

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Jim et al- Don t give up hope yet. There were several Gen-Xers who were regular attendees at the monthly kantei-kai. Most notably the young Mr Fujishiro and
messages.messageBody:
Jim et al-
Don't give up hope yet. There were several "Gen-Xers" who were regular
attendees at the monthly kantei-kai. Most notably the young Mr
Fujishiro and his friends (there were always three or four), they
always dressed sharp and took the whole thing very seriously. While
others used the Dokuhon, they used only the Fujishiro Jiten and often
left early having sussed out the swords with their first bids. There
are young polishers and collectors out there, several young ladies who
study at the Sanno, and others who I am I am sure we never run into.
Who will be the next leaders? Can't say for sure but they are there...
-t

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, Hagihara-sensei and Tanobe-sensei seem to still be seen as the young guys in Japan.  I m a little concerned about your point as well.  I asked about any
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
Hagihara-sensei and Tanobe-sensei seem to still be seen as the young guys in Japan. I'm a little concerned about your point as well. I asked about any younger people seriously studying fittings a few years ago and the reply was that they're only interested in clothes, cars and vacations. Also, that nobody gets interested in antiques until they're fifty. Certainly the people you mention got started younger than that. Anyone have some more up to date information?
Jim



All, as an off topic on this, I was talking with a mate the other day on
the sad passing of Fujishiro sensei and how these great men are being
replaced. Cary Condell speaks very highly of Fujishiro Matsuo's son,
Fujishiro Okisato and I take him on his word on this matter. It is
wonderful to know this organization is in good hands. My friend and I
were also talking of other more "singular" giants of nihonto such as
Shibata Sensei and who his replacement would be in his business. This
led me to Hagihara Sensei, does he have a protege ?, who will replace
him when he passes on or retires ?. Is there much in the way of up and
coming's in line after the likes of Shibata, Tanobe and other sensei ?.

Rich Turner

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Inquiry
messages.msgSnippet: Arnold, guys - Yes, I too wondered about kodogu shinsa, having several signed kinko tsuba that could benefit from a respected peer s okay-dokay! It would be
messages.messageBody:
Arnold, guys -

Yes, I too wondered about kodogu shinsa, having several signed kinko tsuba that could benefit from a respected peer's okay-dokay! It would be good to know the judge's strong areas of kantie.

Has anybody heard how the shinsa slots are going for Chicago? Are they approaching a full booking or not? I was going to call Coleman and ask (which I might still do) but perhaps the question has already been answered.

Ron
STL

>>> jggilbert@... 06/23/04 5:10 PM >>>
Rich,
At least it is someone interpreting the Kaneie style. The motif is a
memento mori as you say. Sometimes that motif is tied to Sekigahara,
but seems like it could fit any battle.

Jim
